description: Move you camera until white dots will display in your screen. Touch at any white dots to start your learning!
Alright class, buckle up for a journey into the heart of reproduction the amazing process of fertilization!
This is where sperm and egg meet, setting the stage for the development of a new life.
Imagine millions of tiny swimmers sperm cells released by the male during sexual reproduction.
Their mission is to reach and fertilize an egg cell (ovum) released by the female.
Sperm travel from the vagina through the cervix and into the fallopian tubes,
where the egg is waiting. This journey can take hours or even days.
Here's where things get interesting: The female reproductive system has natural
barriers that help select the strongest sperm. Only the healthiest and most motile
(able to move) sperm will make it to the egg. Acrosomal Reaction: Once a sperm reaches the egg,
a special structure on its head called the acrosome releases enzymes. These enzymes help the
perm penetrate the egg's outer protective layer, the zona pellucida. The Big Moment: Fusion!
Only one sperm can successfully fertilize the egg. Once a sperm penetrates the zona pellucida,
a change occurs in the egg's membrane that prevents other sperm from entering.
The sperm's nucleus then fuses with the egg's nucleus, creating a single cell called a zygote.

The fertilized zygote starts dividing rapidly, traveling down the fallopian tube towards
the uterus. This early stage of development is called a blastocyst. Once it reaches
the uterus, the blastocyst implants itself into the uterine lining, where it will continue
to grow and develop into an embryo. The process of fertilization is a delicate dance
between the sperm and egg, ensuring the creation of a new individual with a unique genetic makeup.
That is all class! Thank you for listening see you in our next lesson!
